questiontext.text: Determine zz such that P(Z<z)=0.29P(Z<z)=0.29. In other words, what zz-score is greater than 2929% of standard normal values? (Answers within 0.01 from the correct value will be marked correct.)

generalfeedback.text:
Start with a sketch. Leftward numbers (toward −∞-\infty) will be less than our boundary zz, so we shade a left region with area 0.29.


You should go to your zz-table and find the zz-score with the left area closest to 0.29.

zz P(Z<z)P(Z<z)
-0.58 0.281
-0.57 0.2843
-0.56 0.2877
-0.55 0.2912
-0.54 0.2946
-0.53 0.2981

It turns out the exact answer is z=−0.5533847z=-0.5533847, which could be found by using an inverse normal function. On a spreadsheet:

=Norm.Inv(0.29,0,1)

Using R:

qnorm(0.29)

But, the zz-table is accurate enough, so I will accept either -0.56 or -0.55 (anything within 0.01 of -0.5533847).

You might find it helpful to visualize with a spinner.

questiontext.text: Determine zz such that P(Z>z)=0.22P(Z>z)=0.22. In other words, what zz-score is less than 2222% of standard normal values? (Answers within 0.01 from the correct value will be marked correct.)

generalfeedback.text:
Start with a sketch. Rightward numbers (toward +∞+\infty) will be more than our boundary zz, so we shade a rightward region with area 0.22.


You should first find the left area. P(Z<z)=1−P(Z>z)=1−0.22=0.78\begin{aligned} P(Z<z) &= 1-P(Z>z) \\ &= 1-0.22 \\ &= 0.78 \end{aligned}

plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-2

You should go to your zz-table and find the zz-score with the left area closest to 0.78.

zz P(Z<z)P(Z<z)
0.75 0.7734
0.76 0.7764
0.77 0.7794
0.78 0.7823
0.79 0.7852
0.8 0.7881

It turns out the exact answer is z=0.7721932z=0.7721932, which could be found by using an inverse normal function. On a spreadsheet:

=Norm.Inv(0.78,0,1)

Using R:

rightarea = 0.22
leftarea = 1-rightarea
qnorm( leftarea )

But, the zz-table is accurate enough, so I will accept either 0.77 or 0.78 (anything within 0.01 of 0.7721932).

You might find it helpful to visualize with a spinner.

questiontext.text: Determine zz such that P(|Z|<z)=0.52P(|Z|<z)=0.52. In other words, how far from 0 should boundaries be set such that 52% of standard normal values are between those boundaries? (Answers within 0.01 from the correct value will be marked correct.)

generalfeedback.text:
Start with a sketch.


Method 1: Determine the area of each tail. Both tails have the same area, and all three areas add to 1. Thus, P(Z>z)=1−0.522=0.24P(Z>z) = \frac{1-0.52}{2} = 0.24

P(Z<z)=0.24+0.52=0.76\begin{aligned} P(Z<z) &= 0.24+0.52 \\ &= 0.76 \end{aligned}

You should go to your zz-table and find the zz-score with the left area closest to 0.76.

zz P(Z<z)P(Z<z)
0.68 0.7517
0.69 0.7549
0.7 0.758
0.71 0.7611
0.72 0.7642
0.73 0.7673

It turns out the exact answer is z=0.7063026z=0.7063026, which could be found by using an inverse normal function. On a spreadsheet:

=Norm.Inv(0.76,0,1)

Using R:

centralarea = 0.52
leftarea = (1-centralarea)/2 + centralarea
qnorm( leftarea )

But, because we are using the zz-table, I will accept either 0.7 or 0.71. (Or, really anything within 0.01 of 0.7063026.)

Method 2: Another way to get 0.76 is by adding half of 0.52 to 0.5. P(Z<z)=0.522+0.5=0.26+0.5=0.76P(Z<z) ~=~ \frac{0.52}{2}+0.5~=~ 0.26+0.5 ~=~ 0.76


Then, use the table. Or, you could use R:

centralarea = 0.52
leftarea = 0.5 + centralarea/2
qnorm( leftarea )

It might be helpful to visualize with a spinner.

questiontext.text: Determine zz such that P(|Z|>z)=0.12P(|Z|>z)=0.12. In other words, how far from 0 should boundaries be set such that 12% of standard normal values are outside those boundaries? (Answers within 0.01 from the correct value will be marked correct.)

generalfeedback.text:
Start with a sketch. The total two-tail area is 0.12, so each tail has half that area.


Method 1: Determine the area of each tail and the center. Both tails have the same area, and all three areas add to 1. Thus, P(Z>z)=0.122=0.06P(Z>z) = \frac{0.12}{2} = 0.06

P(Z<−z)=0.122=0.06P(Z<-z) = \frac{0.12}{2} = 0.06

P(|Z|<z)=1−P(|Z|>z)=1−0.12=0.88\begin{aligned} P(|Z|<z) &= 1-P(|Z|>z) \\ &= 1-0.12 \\ &= 0.88 \end{aligned}

Find the left area.

P(Z<z)=0.06+0.88=0.94\begin{aligned} P(Z<z) &= 0.06+0.88 \\ &= 0.94 \end{aligned}

You should go to your zz-table and find the zz-score with the left area closest to 0.94.

zz P(Z<z)P(Z<z)
1.53 0.937
1.54 0.9382
1.55 0.9394
1.56 0.9406
1.57 0.9418
1.58 0.9429

It turns out the exact answer is z=1.5547736z=1.5547736, which could be found by using an inverse normal function. On a spreadsheet:

=Norm.Inv(0.94,0,1)

Using R:

twotailarea = 0.12
onetailarea = twotailarea/2
centralarea = 1-twotailarea
leftarea = onetailarea + centralarea
qnorm( leftarea )

Method 2: Another way to get 0.94 is by subtracting half of 0.12 from 1. P(Z<z)=1−0.122=1−0.06=0.94P(Z<z) ~=~ 1-\frac{0.12}{2}~=~ 1-0.06 ~=~ 0.94


Then, use the table. Or, R:

twotailarea = 0.12
leftarea = 1 - twotailarea/2
qnorm( leftarea )

You might find a spinner visualization useful.
